thread.section_title: Latest business and finance news from New Zealand and the world's key markets - Yahoo New Zealand Finance
thread.title: Dreamworld owner suffers profit slide

title: Dreamworld owner suffers profit slide
text:
Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 2:44 AM NZST - New Zealand Markets open in 7 hrs 16 mins Dreamworld owner suffers profit slide AAP – 6 hours ago Print 
Dreamworld owner Ardent Leisure's full year profit has slumped by more than a third as it looks to import the winning formula of its US family entertainment businesses to Australia. 
Ardent Leisure's revenue rose 19 per cent to $594.6 million, but its profit fell 34 per cent to $32 million because of one-off cash costs from restructuring and the closure of three bowling centres. 
The group's Main Event Entertainment division in the US lifted earnings by more than 60 per cent with the business now contributing 35 per cent of the company's overall earnings, up from 21 per cent. 
Ardent chief executive Deborah Thomas confirmed the group's plans to expand in the next two years. 
"Main Event plans to open a further seven centres in FY2016 and eight in FY2017," she said. 
"However, we consider there is potential for further growth over the next two years and management is actively pursing opportunities for additional new sites." 
The company is considering replicating the successful US formula of multiple indoor attractions in Australia to revive its bowling alleys. 
The recently opened Kingpin Darwin, which saw an expansion from bowling to include the Main Event recipe of arcade games and other activities, enjoyed strong opening trade. 
"The combination of bowling, arcade games, laser skirmish, great food and coffee has been well received in the Northern Territory," Ms Thomas said. 
Gold Coast theme park revenues and earnings were up 2.4 per cent which is considered a solid result given unprecedented rainfall and Cyclone Marcia slamming the attractions in the third quarter. 
The unorthodox combination of baby tigers and the weaker Australian dollar is expected to lift the theme park performance in the coming year. 
A tiger cub born in July 2015 is expected to lure visitors in the September school holidays, with Dreamworld's exotic animals providing an edge over other Gold Coast attractions. 
"Tigers and animals are our unique selling point proposition against competition," said Ms Thomas. 
The weakening Australian dollar is expected to keep Australians holidaying nearby while encouraging international visitors. @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Reject Shop says profit growth will return AAP 
The Reject Shop expects to return to profit growth for the first time in four years as it pins its hope on everyday …
